entry.title: FIFA: Blatter resignation won't lead many to quit
entry.summary:
He is also being investigated for $10 million in bribes paid to land the event, part of the corruption scandal that pushed FIFA President Blatter to resign.

RIO DE JANEIRO (AP) - A consistent ally of Sepp Blatter, Danny Jordaan already has a new job.

entry.title: FIFA election chief reminds Blatter of need to step down
entry.summary: Sepp Blatter was warned from within FIFA on Sunday not to attempt to backtrack on his pledge to quit as president.

entry.title: FIFA election chief reminds Blatter of need to step down
entry.summary: ZURICH (AP) " The official overseeing the next FIFA presidential election has reminded Sepp Blatter to stick with his plans to step down.

entry.title: Blatter may seek to stay as FIFA boss, source tells Swiss paper
entry.summary: Blatter's renewed interest in the job was also a reason for the departure of Walter de Gregorio as FIFA's director of communications, since he had argued for a completely new start and advised Blatter to go, the Swiss newspaper said.

entry.title: Blatter may seek to stay as FIFA boss, source tells Swiss paper
entry.summary:
GENEVA (Reuters) - Sepp Blatter may seek to stay on as the president of FIFA, a Swiss newspaper quoted an anonymous source close to Blatter as saying on Sunday.

The Schweiz am Sonntag newspaper said it had information that Blatter had received messages of support from African and Asian football associations, asking him to rethink his decision to step down.

entry.title: WRAPUP 1-Blatter's exit prompts call for new face, fresh start for FIFA
entry.summary: Blatter has not been charged with any wrongdoing.

entry.title: FIFA says Valcke not behind $10M payment in corruption probe (Yahoo Sports)
entry.summary: Prince Ali, the Jordanian who lost to Blatter in last week's presidential election, told CNN that Blatter should resign because of the widening scandal.

entry.title: EU parliament urges Blatter to quit FIFA immediately
entry.summary:
The European Parliament said Blatter's failure to depart immediately would block efforts to rid FIFA of rampant corruption.

EU politicians heaped pressure on Blatter, 79, voting in favour of an eight-page resolution with a series of demands to clean up football.

He also introduced the news conference where Blatter announced his resignation and appeared close to tears as the departing president announced his exit.

The race to succeed Blatter gathered a new challenger on Wednesday when football great Zico formally declared his candidacy for the FIFA presidency, but the Brazilian admitted his chances of success were limited.

entry.title: Blatter quits as FIFA chief after corruption scandal
entry.summary: Blatter, 79, announced the decision at a news conference in Zurich, six days after the FBI raided a hotel in Zurich and arrested several FIFA officials and just four days after he was re-elected to a fifth term as president.

entry.title: Sepp Blatter Says He Will Resign as FIFA President
entry.summary:
FIFA President Sepp Blatter will resign from soccer's governing body amid a widening corruption scandal and has promised to call for fresh elections to choose a successor.

Three days earlier, Blatter was defiant and feisty in the same room when fending off questions about FIFA's battered reputation and the chance U.S. federal agencies could seek his arrest.

entry.title: FIFA's top spokesman leaves job, Blatter urged to do same
entry.summary: FIFA responded by announcing that its executive committee will meet on July 20 in Zurich to decide when from December to February the election to decide Blatter's successor should be held.

entry.title: FIFA's top spokesman leaves job, Blatter urged to do same
entry.summary: De Gregorio joined FIFA after working on Blatter's campaign team during the 2011 presidential election.

entry.title: EU lawmakers urge FIFA's Blatter to go now
entry.summary: "The European Parliament... therefore calls on FIFA to select, in a transparent and inclusive way, an appropriate interim leader to replace Joseph Blatter forthwith."

entry.title: European lawmakers urge FIFA president Blatter to go now
entry.summary:
STRASBOURG, France (AP) - European lawmakers have urged FIFA President Sepp Blatter to step down immediately, and for an interim leader to be appointed.

FIFA rules require senior vice president Issa Hayatou of Cameroon to step up as interim president if Blatter leaves before the election.

entry.title: FIFA shelves bidding for 2026 World Cup, seeks Blatter replacement
entry.summary: Scandal-plagued FIFA postponed the bidding for the right to host the 2026 World Cup on Wednesday and embarked on the search to find a replacement for outgoing President Sepp Blatter.

entry.title: UEFA President Michel Platini says he won't talk about FIFA
entry.summary: Platini, a former France great and a leading candidate to replace Blatter as FIFA president, spoke Wednesday after meeting with French President Francois Hollande.

entry.title: FIFA to kick off Blatter succession process in July
entry.summary: "This extraordinary Executive Committee will convene in July, the precise date to be confirmed within this week. For this extraordinary elective Congress (to elect Blatter's successor) there are currently various date options for discussion."

entry.title: Sepp Blatter exit date to be decided next month, December departure for Fifa president an option
entry.summary: Fifa has announced the date for the election of Sepp Blatter's successor as president will be decided next month - with December 16 a likely option - and postponed the bidding process for the 2026 World Cup.

entry.title: Blatter says he will forgive but won't forget UEFA rebellion
entry.summary:
"I forgive but I don't forget," Blatter said Saturday at FIFA headquarters.

"(UEFA) have to be an example also and not only to say, 'FIFA, what is FIFA?' They shall help and come in and take responsibility," Blatter said.

The executive committee also cleared the way for European countries to bid for the 2026 World Cup, despite previous comments by Blatter that it would be too soon after Russia hosts the 2018 tournament.

"You cannot take (responsibility) when you are elected and you don't even come to the first meeting," Blatter said.

entry.title: Blatter slams england rep's boycott
entry.summary: Uefa president Michel Platini personally asked Mr Blatter to resign over the corruption scandal, and appealed for members to vote him out at yesterday's closely watched election battle.

entry.title: Blatter criticises US justice chief
entry.summary: Blatter then suggested the US Department of Justice went too far in its actions which brought a torrent of condemnation down on Fifa, which he has led for 17 years.

entry.title: Sepp Blatter makes special mention of his Oceania support
0-Blatter wins fifth FIFA term as challenger concedes
entry.summary:
Neither Blatter nor Jordanian opponent Prince Ali bin Al Hussein received the necessary two thirds of votes in the first round, with Blatter securing 133 votes against 73 for Prince Ali.

"I congratulate you if you voted for Prince Ali, he was a good candidate, but I am the president now, the president of everybody," the 79-year-old Blatter said in his victory speech, knowing he faces a barrage of criticism and countless problems.

Blatter's future could yet depend on the reaction of FIFA's major sponsors and stakeholders who have been deeply dismayed by the dawn arrests in Zurich on Wednesday of several FIFA officials and U.S. prosecutors announcing indictments of officials and companies.

entry.title: Africa promises Blatter unanimous support
entry.summary: "I'm a happy man," Blatter said.

entry.title: FIFA email connects Sepp Blatter to $10M, newspaper claims
entry.summary: FIFA said in a statement to The Associated Press on Sunday that sending money to Warner was the idea of the South African government and Blatter was being updated by Mbeki in their discussions.

entry.title: FIFA email connects Sepp Blatter to $10M, newspaper claims
entry.summary: The newspaper said that in the email, which was not published, Valcke wrote that the $10 million was "based on discussions between FIFA and the South African government, and also between our President (Blatter) and President Thabo Mbeki."

entry.title: Disgraced Blatter starts FIFA reform work
Disgraced FIFA president starts work on reforms amid crisis
entry.summary:
"Working hard on reforms after meeting Audit & Compliance Committee Independent Chairman Scala," Blatter wrote, along with a link to a statement released by FIFA.

In his statement on Thursday, the first since calling for new elections to find a successor, Blatter said he met with FIFA audit panel chairman Domenico Scala "to establish a framework for action and a timetable" for his final months.

"I want a comprehensive program of reform and I am very aware that only the FIFA Congress can pass these reforms," Blatter said in the statement.

entry.title: FIFA: Blatter resignation won't lead many to quit
entry.summary:
FIFA President Sepp Blatter leaves after speaking at a press conference at the FIFA headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, Tuesday, June 2, 2015.

FILE - In this Sunday, Nov. 25, 2007 file photo FIFA President Sepp Blatter rubs his eye as he speaks at a press conference at the ICC in Durban, South Africa.

entry.title: Sport24.co.za | Former FIFA VP Warner fingers Blatter
entry.summary:
Warner also said that when he heard Blatter was stepping down, he wrote him to urge his immediate departure from FIFA.

"Blatter knows why he fell. And if anyone else knows, I do," Warner said.

entry.title: A tumultuous week ends as Blatter gets standing ovation
entry.summary: Warner said he has documents and checks that link FIFA officials, including embattled President Sepp Blatter, to the 2010 election in Trinidad and Tobago.

entry.title: FIFA executive committee member Blazer admitted bribes
entry.summary: FIFA President Sepp Blatter, who has run the governing body since 1998, said Tuesday he will be resigning, an announcement made six days after the indictments were unsealed and four days after he was elected to a fifth term.

entry.title: The Latest: German Soccer Chief Wants Blatter Successor Soon
entry.summary: The Jordanian Football Association says it is studying FIFA rules to see whether they allow for the possibility of Prince Ali bin al-Hussein succeeding President Sepp Blatter without going to an election first.

entry.title: The Latest: German soccer chief wants Blatter successor soon
entry.summary:
German football federation president Wolfgang Niersbach wants a successor to outgoing FIFA president Sepp Blatter to be named much sooner than currently planned.

He said Michael van Praag of the Netherlands was an ideal candidate to replace Blatter.

Meanwhile, German Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere called for structural reforms to be made to FIFA in the wake of Blatter's announced resignation as president of world soccer's governing body.

His comments late Tuesday came hours after FIFA's top official, Sepp Blatter, stepped down amid a U.S. probe into $150 million in bribes allegedly paid to top soccer officials.

entry.title: The Latest: German soccer chief wants Blatter successor soon
Sepp Blatter back at work at FIFA headquarters
entry.summary: A day after announcing his decision to resign, Sepp Blatter was back at work at FIFA headquarters on Wednesday as the worst corruption crisis in the governing body's 111-year history continued to unfold.

entry.title: The Latest: Russia Says 2018 World Cup Won't Be Affected
entry.summary: Russia, which was a staunch supporter of Blatter, says it will continue to work with him until he steps down and a new election for FIFA president is held.

entry.title: Platini Cancels UEFA Meeting on Anti-Blatter Tactics
entry.summary:
UEFA has canceled a meeting in Berlin this weekend where member federations were to discuss ways of opposing a Sepp Blatter-led FIFA.

UEFA President Michel Platini says it is better to await developments after Blatter announced plans to resign.

entry.title: Sepp Blatter's daughter says quit decision not tied to allegations-Blick
entry.summary: Sepp Blatter rocked the world of soccer on Tuesday by saying he would step down as FIFA president in the wake of a corruption investigation that now includes the 79-year-old chief himself.

entry.title: Global reaction to Sepp Blatter's decision to resign

entry.title: Blatter says he will resign as FIFA president
entry.summary: Blatter joined FIFA in 1975 as technical director for development projects, was promoted to general secretary in 1981 and spent 17 years as right-hand man to Havelange of Brazil before being elected to lead world soccer.

entry.title: Blatter quits FIFA; under investigation by U.S. prosecutors, FBI
entry.summary: FIFA did not respond to a request for comment on Blatter being under investigation.

entry.title: Sponsors say Blatter resignation one step in FIFA reform
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (AP) - For FIFA's top sponsors, the resignation of Sepp Blatter is just the first step in restoring the reputation of soccer's governing body and regaining the fans' trust following a corruption scandal.

Blatter, who is not implicated in any of the charges, said he would step down in an acknowledgement that major change was needed at the top of FIFA.

entry.title: NZ to grill Blatter over agenda, Oceania World Cup place
entry.summary:
Both NZF and the OFC had high expectations Blatter would support direct entry, but FIFA's executive committee decided the current qualification spots would remain the same.

The under-20 World Cup runs in New Zealand until June 20, with Blatter expected to arrive in the country in time for the final in Auckland.

entry.title: FIFA scandal deepens as Blatter aide linked to payments
entry.summary: As new questions arose in the FIFA scandal, more officials were arrested, suspended or banned on Tuesday, and countries were weighing a World Cup boycott amid controversy over the re-election of Blatter as FIFA president.

entry.title: FIFA scandal deepens as Blatter aide linked to payments
entry.summary: Following Blatter's re-election as FIFA president, the English Football Association's chairman Greg Dyke said his organization would support any boycott led by UEFA, the Union of European Football Associations.

entry.title: Report: FIFA's Valcke believed to be behind $10M payment
entry.summary:
A report says the high-ranking FIFA official who allegedly made a $10-million payment central to a U.S. probe into soccer corruption is believed to be Sepp Blatter's right-hand man, Jerome Valcke.

Blatter, who won re-election Friday for a fifth term as FIFA president despite the scandal, has denied being the unidentified high-ranking official named in the indictment as having "caused" the payment.

entry.title: Sepp Blatter, FIFA facing more criticism this week (Yahoo Sports)
entry.summary:
LONDON (AP) -- In the House of Commons, they're calling for Sepp Blatter's head.

While the newly re-elected Blatter seems to be going nowhere despite the arrests and indictments of several soccer officials last week in Zurich, others are calling it quits or threatening to do so.

D'Hooghe has served on FIFA's ruling body since 1988, a decade before Blatter's move up from secretary general to president.

entry.title: Sepp Blatter, FIFA facing more criticism this week
entry.summary: "For the good of the game, it is time for Sepp Blatter to go," British sports and culture secretary John Whittingdale told the House of Commons on Monday.

entry.title: Sepp Blatter, FIFA facing more criticism this week
entry.summary: The debate in Britain, where Blatter faces some of his harshest criticism, made its way to Parliament on Monday, and Whittingdale wasn't alone in his condemnation of the FIFA president.

entry.title: Blatter disgraced FIFA, says former VP Warner
Blatter disgraced FIFA, says former vice-president
entry.summary: No one brought more shame on FIFA than its president Sepp Blatter and he should step aside for a younger leader, the organisation's former vice-president Jack Warner has said.

entry.title: FIFA patronage endears Blatter to 196th-ranked Fiji

You'll have a gigantic party thrown for you, and you can keep your office here at FIFA'," Blatter said, adding that he had refused Platini's invitation to have the conversation over a glass of whiskey.

"Listen, with all the respect to the judicial system of the U.S. with a new minister of justice," Blatter said, "the Americans, if they have a financial crime that regards American citizens then they must arrest these people there and not in Zurich when we have a congress."

entry.title: No surprise: Sepp Blatter re-elected as FIFA president
entry.summary: The 209 FIFA member federations gave the 79-year-old Blatter another four-year term after Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan conceded defeat after losing 133-73 in the first round.

entry.title: Blatter's future as president at stake in FIFA election
entry.summary:
A two-thirds majority would be enough for Blatter or Prince Ali to win the secret presidential vote, or a simple majority in a second round of voting.

Just forcing the ballot to a second round could represent a victory of sorts for Blatter's critics, denying the incumbent president an emphatic mandate in his next term.

entry.title: Blatter set to win new term despite football corruption scandal
entry.summary: Some countries that have supported Blatter said they were switching allegiance following the scandal, but the numbers still appeared to favour his re-election.

Canada also said it would not support Blatter.

entry.title: Bomb threat at FIFA congress

entry.title: Amid crisis and ahead of vote, Blatter calls for 'unity' at FIFA

entry.title: Blatter seeks re-election as scandal engulfs FIFA
entry.summary: Adding to the pressure on FIFA and Blatter, there are growing concerns from major sponsors, many of whom have solidly backed the organisation despite nearly 20 years of bribery and corruption allegations.

entry.title: Blatter seeks re-election as scandal engulfs FIFA
entry.summary:
At a meeting in Zurich starting at 0730 GMT, up to 209 FIFA members will choose between Blatter, who is seeking his fifth term as president, and his sole challenger Prince Ali bin Al Hussein of Jordan.

On Friday, New Zealand Football said it would vote for 39-year-old Prince Ali despite a previous unanimous commitment from countries in the Oceania Football Confederation in January to back Blatter.

entry.title: Australia want Blatter ousted from FIFA
Why Blatter will win FIFA election again
entry.summary:
Sepp Blatter, a 79-year-old Swiss native who had been Havelange's top aide, defeated Sweden's Lennart Johansson, then the president of UEFA, 111-80 on the first ballot in 1998.

A former French national team captain, Platini replaced Johansson as UEFA president in 2007 and has been viewed as a possible Blatter successor.

entry.title: FIFA Congress with Sepp Blatter gives off florid stench of corruption

entry.title: Defiant Soccer Chief Resists Calls to Resign Amid Scandal
entry.summary: As defiant as ever, Sepp Blatter resisted calls to resign as FIFA president Thursday and deflected blame for the massive bribery and corruption scandal engulfing soccer's world governing body.

entry.title: Defiant soccer chief resists calls to resign amid scandal
entry.summary:
Blatter refused to back down after European soccer body UEFA demanded earlier Thursday that he quit following the latest - and most serious allegations - to discredit FIFA during his 17 years in office.

Blatter said the crisis could mark a "turning point" for FIFA to clean itself up.

entry.title: FIFA challenger says he was offered Blatter's financial info
entry.summary:
However, the Jordanian prince - a FIFA vice president - did not notify football's governing body of the attempt to corrupt the election or that Blatter's purported private information was apparently being touted.

On Friday, Blatter, who has been FIFA president since 1998, will face the first contested vote for the job since 2002.

Information about the alleged offer to help oust Blatter was released in a statement from Quest, a corporate intelligence firm run by former London police commissioner John Stevens.

entry.title: FIFA challenger says he was offered Blatter's financial info
entry.summary: The challenger's campaign said Monday it was approached by an individual who offered details on Blatter's finances and claimed to be able to help deliver dozens of votes in the head-to-head contest for the FIFA presidency.

entry.title: Platini: FIFA led by Blatter will always lack credibility
entry.summary:
Blatter is clinging to power "at all costs," Platini told French sports daily L'Equipe in an interview published on Monday.

Ahead of the FIFA presidential election on Friday, Platini said the 79-year-old Blatter had no grand plans for FIFA and it was "not credible" to claim he needed a fifth four-year term to complete an unfinished mission.

"I understand the fear of that emptiness that he (Blatter) must have, it's natural. But if he really loves FIFA, he should have put its interests ahead of his own."

Though Platini said he likes Blatter on a personal level, his explicit criticism of the FIFA chief points to a deep rift between the two men.

He opted last August not to challenge Blatter in the election of 209 FIFA member federations and now supports the only opponent: FIFA vice president Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan.

Platini, now 59, was a key campaigner helping Blatter become FIFA president in 1998 and then a long-time heir apparent.

entry.title: Blatter set for big presidential win in a rare FIFA election held without corruption claims
entry.summary:
It adds up to Blatter being able to count on most voters in five of FIFA's six continental confederations during his reign.

Meanwhile, FIFA protocol allowed Blatter to address all those meetings, without explicitly referring to the election.

entry.title: NEWSMAKER-Soccer-Why Blatter will remain supreme as The Pope of Football
entry.summary:
Five of FIFA's six continental confederations publicly expressed their support for Blatter before the World Cup in Brazil last year, with UEFA declaring its opposition, meaning the vast majority of FIFA's 209 members will vote for him.

Michel D'Hooge, 68, the honorary president of the Belgian FA and a FIFA executive committee member since 1988, has no doubts about why Blatter cannot be toppled.

entry.title: Why Blatter will remain supreme as The Pope of Football
entry.summary: But like every allegation thrown at him since he first became president in 1998, Blatter has emerged unscathed and will almost certainly be voted back into office on May 29.

entry.title: FIFA's Sepp Blatter: I'm not trying to avoid FBI
entry.summary: "That is a good idea and you are not so far away," Blatter said.

entry.title: Blatter to Visit US in 2016, Rejects Talk of Avoiding FBI
entry.summary:
Sepp Blatter says he has no fear of setting foot in the United States - no matter what the FBI might be doing.

In fact, Blatter plans an American visit in June 2016 for the Copa America tournament.

The single page document - including the slogan "Develop the game, touch the world and build a better future" - is as near as Blatter has come to a campaign manifesto for a fifth presidential term.

entry.title: Blatter to visit US in 2016, rejects talk of avoiding FBI
Sepp Blatter: I?ve tried to tame soccer?s monstrous success
entry.summary: "I am the president and not a candidate," Blatter said.

entry.title: Blatter: I've tried to tame soccer's monstrous success
Blatter: I've tried to tame soccer's monstrous success
entry.summary:
FIFA President Sepp Blatter says he has tried to "tame the monster" of soccer's success during his 17-year reign.

Blatter says predecessor Joao Havelange once told him: "Sepp, you created a monster."

In reply, Blatter says he told Havelange: "Yes, but I try to tame the monster."

Blatter says the power of soccer is "wonderful even if at the same time it's scary."

entry.title: Israeli FA presses Blatter in effort to avert suspension
entry.summary:
Blatter met Israeli Football Association (IFA) chairman Ofer Eini and chief executive Rotem Kamer to discuss the PFA request for the vote at a FIFA Congress on May 29.

Two years ago, FIFA established a task force which included Blatter, the Israeli and Palestinian FA chiefs and the heads of the European and Asian confederations to try to resolve the Palestinian complaints.

entry.title: Israeli FA presses Blatter in effort to avert suspension
entry.summary: Earlier, an IFA official told Reuters that Eini and Kamer would urge Blatter to use his influence to strike the PFA proposal from the Congress agenda.

entry.title: Sport24.co.za | Blatter praises Asian soccer
entry.summary:
Manama - FIFA president Sepp Blatter praised the president of the Asian Football Confederation Shaikh Salman of Bahrain for "cleaning up" the confederation in a speech to delegates at the AFC's congress on Thursday.

Blatter told delegates from the 47 Asian nations that Salman had shown "a remarkable sense of organisation and diplomacy to bring back the boat of the AFC that at certain times has been in waters not so very clear and not so very clean."

Blatter's support for the Bahraini was only to be expected as Salman declared the AFC's support for Blatter after its extra-ordinary congress in Australia in January.

However, Blatter's speech lacked his usual vibrancy and at the end he received warm, rather than overwhelming applause from the delegates.

entry.title: -CONCACAF congress turns into pro-Blatter rally
entry.summary: "We knew in advance there was support for Mr Blatter in this region," Van Praag told Reuters.

entry.title: Blatter says CONCACAF should get extra World Cup slot
entry.summary: But Blatter, who is seeking a fifth term as president of FIFA, suggested it was time for a change.

entry.title: Blatter says CONCACAF should get extra World Cup slot
Blatter likened to Jesus & Mandela
entry.summary:
"Membership is sending a message that we continue to support Blatter," said Concafaf president Jeffrey Webb.

The Trinidad & Tobago Football Association praised Blatter, 79, as the "father of football".

entry.title: Blatter says CONCACAF should be given extra slot in World Cup
entry.summary: "If the World Cup will stay at 32 teams, then CONCACAF should have four teams," Blatter said to applause from delegates at the CONCACAF congress.

entry.title: Maradona says election chance to kick Blatter in 'rear end'
entry.summary: Maradona is in Colombia to play an exhibition game called the "Game for Peace," but he could not resist weighing in on Blatter's bid for his fifth consecutive term to head soccer's governing body.

entry.title: Maradona says election chance to kick Blatter in 'rear end'
entry.summary:
Diego Maradona says the upcoming FIFA election offers a chance "to kick (Sepp) Blatter in the rear end."

Maradona, who has had a long-running feud with Blatter, says he is supporting FIFA vice president Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan.

entry.title: Luis Figo disputes all of Africa is behind Sepp Blatter in FIFA presidential elections
entry.summary: FIFA presidential candidate Luis Figo on Wednesday disputed the Confederation of African Football's claim that all 54 votes from the continent will go to incumbent Sepp Blatter in the presidential elections next month.

entry.title: Blatter says Russia must fight racism after fresh incident
entry.summary: MOSCOW (AP) " FIFA president Sepp Blatter says there is still a "lot of work to be done" to fight racism in 2018 World Cup host Russia.

entry.title: Blatter says Russia must fight racism after fresh incident
Figo disputes CAF claim of all-Africa backing for Blatter
entry.summary: When Blatter came to power in 1998, Hayatou pledged Africa's votes to rival Lennart Johansson of Sweden but most defied him to vote Blatter into power.

entry.title: Africa divided over Blatter - Figo
entry.summary:
"Even when he announced he would support Blatter, we could notice a difference from past congresses when a statement like that normally is followed by a standing ovation.

The Caf congress ended on Tuesday with Hayatou declaring Africa's complete support for Blatter's re-election but on all previous occasions when the Caf chief has promised a block of African votes, many have broken ranks.

And in 2002, when Hayatou stood against Blatter, almost half the African countries voted against their own confederation president.

entry.title: All African nations say they?ll vote for FIFA?s Blatter
entry.summary: Blatter said he was due to meet Palestine football federation President Jibril Rajoub in Cairo later Tuesday.

entry.title: Africa promises Blatter unanimous support
entry.summary: Africa's expected show of support for Blatter indicated that while the appetite for change at the top of world soccer is strong in Europe, it isn't everywhere else.

entry.title: Africa promises Blatter unanimous support
entry.summary:
"Africa is comfortable having you. Africa stays with you," Hayatou said to Blatter, according to a transcript of his comments provided by CAF.

Although the individual countries don't have to follow Hayatou's directive, the continent is expected to be a strong base of support for Blatter when he seeks a fifth term to extend a presidency that began in 1998.

entry.title: Sport24.co.za | Blatter to get Africa's vote
entry.summary:
"His action in favour of Africa speaks for him. To us, he is still the man of the situation," Cameroonian Hayatou said at the start of CAF's two-day general assembly in Cairo attended by Blatter.

Blatter's three rivals also attended the two-day CAF meeting as observers.

entry.title: African football chief affirms support for Blatter
entry.summary: Blatter brought the World Cup to Africa for the first time in 2010 and FIFA's financial support has helped keep many African national federations afloat.

entry.title: Hayatou: All of Africa will vote for Blatter
entry.summary:
In front of Blatter's three challengers, Issa Hayatou, president of the Confederation of African Football, promised unanimous support in his speech to open CAF's annual congress in Cairo.

Hayatou, a FIFA vice president and now an ally of Blatter after failing to unseat him in 2002, made an apparent reference to that UEFA congress on Tuesday.

entry.title: Hayatou: All of Africa will vote for Blatter
entry.summary:
CAIRO (AP) " The head of African football says his entire continent will back Sepp Blatter for re-election as FIFA president next month.

Hayatou referred to Blatter as "dear Sepp," and said CAF's 54 member countries would all vote for the 79-year-old Swiss in FIFA's presidential election in Zurich on May 29.

entry.title: Hayatou: All of Africa will vote for Blatter
entry.summary: Hayatou said Blatter was "at home" in Africa and not in "hostile territory," an apparent reference to the criticism Blatter received when he attended the UEFA congress last month.

entry.title: Blatter calls for racism crackdown
entry.summary: And Blatter reminded African countries of extensive financial support to the continent's football associations from world football's governing body as he opened the congress.

entry.title: Blatter back among friends: Africa ready to show its support
entry.summary: Blatter and FIFA vice president Hayatou - now allies after Blatter easily beat Hayatou to be re-elected in 2002 - remain all-powerful in Africa.

entry.title: Prince Ali expects sponsors to snub FIFA if Blatter stays
entry.summary:
FIFA presidential candidate Prince Ali bin al-Hussein believes the scandal-hit organization will struggle to replace sponsors and be hurt financially if Sepp Blatter remains in charge.

Prince Ali is one of three candidates trying to stop Blatter being re-elected for a fifth, four-year term in May along with Dutch FA head Michael van Praag and former Portugal international Luis Figo.

entry.title: FIFA challenger Prince Ali in Africa, Blatter's stronghold
entry.summary:
One of three men challenging Blatter for the FIFA presidency in elections in May, Prince Ali's campaign has moved to Africa ahead of the Confederation of African Football's general assembly in Cairo next week.

Blatter will attend CAF's congress as FIFA president, and will make his traditional speech.

The continent is a key battleground if any of the candidates are going to unseat Blatter, who is the clear favorite to win the election in Zurich on May 29 for a fifth term in office, extending a reign at the top of world soccer that began in 1998.

ZIFA President Cuthbert Dube, previously a Blatter supporter, said Prince Ali's visit highlighted "important issues that Zimbabwe needs more representation in FIFA and CAF so that the country benefits."

entry.title: Platini re-elected as Blatter sits through criticism
entry.summary: Sepp Blatter sat through the day-long proceedings as a guest and had to endure some stinging criticism from his challengers for the FIFA presidency who were invited to make presentations to delegates.

entry.title: Platini re-elected as Blatter sits through criticism
entry.summary: However, that did not seem to be the case with Blatter's opponents.

entry.title: Blatter listens to campaign speeches from 3 rivals
entry.summary:
FIFA President Sepp Blatter listened to campaign speeches from his three challengers on Tuesday, hearing how badly his rivals want to change the organization he has been running for 16 years.

None of the three directly turned to Blatter, who was sitting in the front row during the annual UEFA congress, but Michael van Praag spoke last and voiced the harshest criticism toward the man he hopes to succeed after the May 29 election.

Standing for re-election for a fifth term, Blatter turned down UEFA's invitation to make a campaign speech alongside his rivals.

"I have delivered my speech for unity and solidarity," Blatter told The Associated Press.

Blatter praised IOC President Thomas Bach and the president of the German soccer federation, Wolfgang Niersbach, for voicing their outspoken rejection of any calls for World Cup boycotts.

entry.title: Muted UEFA response as Blatter calls for unity
Prince Ali: Blatter playing politics with FIFA WCup slots
entry.summary:
FIFA's executive committee will give each continent its 2018 World Cup qualifying slots at a special session on May 30 - the day after the election where Blatter seeks a fifth presidential term.

Though Blatter is strongly favored to extend his 17-year reign leading football's governing body, Prince Ali insisted the 79-year-old Swiss can be beaten.

entry.title: Prince Ali: Blatter playing politics with FIFA WCup slots
entry.summary:
FIFA presidential candidate Prince Ali bin al-Hussein claims incumbent Sepp Blatter is playing politics with a key World Cup decision.

FIFA vice president Prince Ali told The Associated Press he believes the timing, steered by Blatter, links an issue based on football merit to election promises.

entry.title: Blatter: 'all parts of FIFA' must help lift credibility
entry.summary: Blatter was quoted as asserting that "FIFA is, with the positive emotions that football unleashes, more influential than any country on Earth and any religion."

entry.title: Blatter: 'all parts of FIFA' must help lift credibility
entry.summary: Sepp Blatter is pledging to intensify a reform process at world football's governing body if re-elected as its president but says that "all parts of FIFA" must help raise its credibility.

entry.title: Sepp Blatter Says World Cup Can Help Situation in Ukraine
entry.summary: Forbidden from using his office to solicit votes for his re-election, FIFA President Sepp Blatter instead took time Friday to use his position to help solve the crisis in Ukraine.

entry.title: Sepp Blatter says World Cup can help situation in Ukraine
entry.summary:
"The World Cup in Russia will be able to stabilize all this situation that is in this region of Europe," said Blatter, who has been closely allied to the 2018 host's president, Vladimir Putin.

"Boycotting a World Cup or any sporting event has never brought any solutions to nobody," added Blatter, who has been an International Olympic Committee member for 16 years.

Blatter noted sharply that the Council of Europe had switched their boycott calls in recent months from the World Cup in Qatar to Russia's tournament.

"This is a direct interference," said Blatter, reminding that FIFA - which counts Russian sports minister Vitaly Mutko among its executive committee members - has rules against government meddling in soccer affairs.

"I am not campaigning," Blatter said to the reporters who were briefed that he would not address election issues at a news conference following a two-day session of the FIFA executive committee.

entry.title: Sepp Blatter says World Cup can help situation in Ukraine
